page.title: 05RIVER TRENT
page.content: THE RIVER TRENT Since the Middle Ages the only way to cross the river at Gainsborough was by ferry.In 1791 the Trent Bridge,designed by William Weston was opened for traffic,at a cost of Â£10,000.All persons and vehicles using the bridge had to pay tolls until 1931 when Lindsey county council bought the bridge for Â£130,000 and the collection of tolls ceased.The bridge has 3 arches but river traffic must use the centre arch.Barges carrying sand,gravel or grain,and pleasure boats form the main river traffic. THE EAGRE is the famous tidal wave which comes up the River Trent from the Humber Estuary.It can be seen in June and July.The Eagre is between one and two metres high when it reaches the Trent Bridge at Gainsborough where it breaks up.
